result.markdown:
--- title: "Day 2A" format: html: css: ../styles.css highlight-style: github --- ![](../img/statistics_2780E3.svg){.hero} We resume on Day 2 with a discussion of special data types (for categorical data and missing values), data summarization and exploration, and basic statistical inference. The latter will include various types of correlation, two-sample tests for comparing two groups, and oneway tests for comparing multiple groups. ## Slides [Click here to view the slides in their own window.](./Slides/2A_Slides.html) ## Data Files - yearspubs (professors' salaries by seniority, publications, etc.) - salaries (professors' salaries by rank, discipline, etc.) - interpersonal (patients' interpersonal problems before and after treatment) - elicitation (participants' emotions elicited during different tasks) ## Practice ## Question 1. a) Download the `yearspubs` dataset from the link above and read it into R. b) Estimate the correlation between academics' number of publications (`n_pubs`) and number of citations (`n_cites`) in this sample. c) Compare the average number of citations between male and female academics using a Welch t-test. Which group had more and was the difference significant? d) Estimate the effect size of this difference.

Click here for the answer key
**Answer (a)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) yearspubs <- read_csv("yearspubs.csv") ``` ::: **Answer (b)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(easystats) correlation(yearspubs) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) Parameter1 | Parameter2 | r | 95% CI | t(60) | p ---------------------------------------------------------------------- years_since_phd | n_pubs | 0.65 | [0.48, 0.78] | 6.70 | < .001*** years_since_phd | n_cites | 0.37 | [0.14, 0.57] | 3.11 | 0.007** years_since_phd | salary | 0.51 | [0.29, 0.67] | 4.54 | < .001*** n_pubs | n_cites | 0.34 | [0.10, 0.54] | 2.80 | 0.007** n_pubs | salary | 0.43 | [0.21, 0.62] | 3.72 | 0.002** n_cites | salary | 0.38 | [0.15, 0.58] | 3.19 | 0.007** p-value adjustment method: Holm (1979) Observations: 62 ``` ::: ::: The correlation between number of publications and citations is 0.34. **Answer (c)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} results <- t.test( formula = n_cites ~ sex, data = yearspubs ) model_parameters(results) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Unable to retrieve data from htest object. Returning an approximate effect size using t_to_d(). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} Table: Welch Two Sample t-test |Parameter | Group | Mean_Group1 | Mean_Group2 | Difference | 95% CI | d | CI_low.1 | CI_high.1 | t(60.00) | p | |:---------|:-----:|:-----------:|:-----------:|:----------:|:--------------:|:-----:|:--------:|:---------:|:--------:|:-----:| |n_cites | sex | 37.33 | 42.46 | -5.12 | (-13.60, 3.36) | -0.31 | -13.60 | 3.36 | -1.21 | 0.232 | Alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group female and group male is not equal to 0 ::: ::: Group 2 (Males) had more citations (42.46) than Group 1 (Females) had (37.33) but this difference was not significant ($p=.232$). **Answer (d)** The effect size was $d=-0.31$ but the difference was not significant $(p=.232)$.

## Question 2 Using the `mpg` tibble from the \{tidyverse\} package, statistically test whether cars with the three different drive trains (`drv`) get significantly different city fuel efficiency (`cty`) on average. Calculate the effect size for this difference.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} results <- aov(formula = cty ~ drv, data = mpg) model_parameters(results, effectsize_type = "eta") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} |Parameter | Sum_Squares | df | Mean_Square | F | p | Eta2 | |:---------|:-----------:|:---:|:-----------:|:-----:|:------:|:----:| |drv | 1878.81 | 2 | 939.41 | 92.68 | < .001 | 0.45 | |Residuals | 2341.53 | 231 | 10.14 | | | | Anova Table (Type 1 tests) ::: ::: The effect size was $\eta^2=0.45$ and the difference was significant $(p<.001)$.

## Question 3. Did you bring your own data? If so, load it into R and explore it using the tools we learned this week. Wrangle it a bit and maybe do some basic statistics on it, estimating correlations and comparing group means. ## Readings - [Chapter 15: Factors](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/factors.html) from *R4DS (2E)* - [Part IV: Statistical Theory](https://learningstatisticswithr.com/book/part-iv-statistical-theory.html) from *LSWR* - [Part V: Statistical Tools](https://learningstatisticswithr.com/book/index.html) from *LSWR* - [Correlation Types](https://easystats.github.io/correlation/articles/types.html) from *correlation* package website - [Estimate Means](https://easystats.github.io/modelbased/articles/estimate_means.html) from *modelbased* package website - [Estimate Contrasts](https://easystats.github.io/modelbased/articles/estimate_contrasts.html) from *modelbased* package ::: {.text-center} Continue to Day 2B Materials  » :::
